title: A Discourse on the Miracles of Our Saviour
label: Woolston (1727): A Discourse on the Miracles of Our Saviour
summary:
Woolston dedicates the first of his discourse to Edmund Gibson, the Bishop of London, who had attempted to have him prosecuted for the publication of The Moderator. He then sets out to argue several points: that the healing of bodily diseases, for which Jesus was famous, was neither a proper part of the work of the Messiah nor a good evidence for Jesus’ divine authority (7-19); that the literal understanding of the stories of Jesus’ miracles implies “improbabilities and incredibilities, and the grossest absurdities,” (19-50), among them the driving of the buyers and sellers out of the temple (22-31), the exorcism of the demoniac in which the devils entered into a herd of swine (31-40), and the transfiguration (40-50).
 
He then promises consideration of the turning of water into wine at Cana, the feeding of the multitudes, the curing of the man sick of the palsy, the curing of the blind man with clay and spittle, the raising of Jairus’s daughter from the dead, the cursing of the fig tree, the journey of the magi, the virgin birth, and the resurrection of Jesus. “The history of Jesus’s life,” he writes, “as recorded in the evangelists, is an emblematical representation of his spiritual life in the soul of man; and his miracles are figures of his mysterious operations. The four Gospels are in no part a literal story, but a system of mystical philosophy or theology” (65).

title: Six Discourses on the Miracles of our Saviour
label: Woolston, Six Discourses on the Miracles of our Saviour
summary:
Thomas Woolston’s Six Discourses on the Miracles of Our Savior was a collection of deistical pieces he published between 1727 and 1729. All of them were designed to show that the miracles attributed to Jesus in the Gospels ought to be understood in an allegorical rather than in a historical or literal sense. Woolston’s professed aim was to strengthen true Christian faith by putting the miracles of Jesus upon their proper footing, but his sarcastic dedications of each of the Discourses to a bishop of the established church and the general tenor of the works made it difficult for his contemporaries to take this profession seriously.
 
Neither the clergy nor the law accepted Woolston’s protestations of his own sincerity, and he was tried, convicted, and imprisoned for blasphemy for the publication of the first five of his Discourses. But they also provoked a tidal wave of responses not only from the bishops of the established church (Gibson, Sherlock, Smallbrook) but also from many dissenting ministers. In turn, Woolston wrote two volumes of responses.

title: Resurrection of Jesus Considered
label: Annet, Resurrection of Jesus Considered
summary:
The Resurrection of Jesus Considered (1744) was Peter Annet’s first major contribution to the deist controversy. The work is an attack on Thomas Sherlock’s Tryal of the Witnesses of the Resurrection (1729). Sherlock was himself responding to Thomas Woolston’s Sixth Discourse on the Miracles of Our Savoiur (1729), and in Annet’s judgment, Woolston had conceded too much, needlessly giving Sherlock premises for his positive argument. Annet argues chiefly for three points: that Jesus did not in fact foretell his resurrection either to the Jewish rulers or to his own disciples, that the story in Matthew of the watch set on Jesus’ tomb is incredible and absurd, and that the accounts given by the four evangelists of Jesus’ resurrection contradict each other at every point.

Every miracle, Annet writes, “is an absurdity to common sense and understanding, and contrary to the attributes of God” (64). And if an alleged event is “contradictory to the constant course of nature,” then even an eyewitness of it would have reason to doubt the veracity of his own eyesight; so much more, then, the should he doubt the judgment or veracity of those who report it to him at second hand (89).

Many of Annet’s arguments in this work were not new, but his vigorous and sarcastic manner of stating his points caught the attention of both Anglican and dissenting ministers. The most noteworthy replies were those by Chandler, Jackson, and Moss, all of whom are summarized in Leland (1754). Annet responded, Chandler rejoined, and the controversy eventually burned itself out.

title: The Sequel of the Trial of the Witnesses
label: Moss, The Sequel of the Trial of the Witnesses
summary:
Moss’s work The Evidence of the Resurrection Cleared from the Exceptions of a Late Pamphlet, published anonymously, was a response to the deist Peter Annet’s Resurrection of Jesus Considered (1744), which was also anonymous. Moss therefore refers throughout to “the Considerer” rather than by the nom de plume on the title page of Annet’s work, “a Moral Philosopher.”

Moss, like Samuel Chandler, contests Annet’s claim that Jesus’ foretelling of his death and resurrection, the story of the guard and the sealing of Jesus’ tomb, and the accounts of the appearances of the angels and of Christ after his resurrection are all unhistorical. He offers resolutions of the various apparent discrepancies in the resurrection narratives. However, some discrepancies between the methods of Chandler and Moss in handling those discrepancies moved Gilbert West to publish his own Observations on the History and Evidence of the Resurrection of Jesus Christ (1747), Annet responded to Moss in The Sequel of the Resurrection of Jesus Considered (1745?) and The Resurrection Defenders Stript of All Defence (1745), in both of which he refers to Moss as “the Clearer.”

Later editions (1749) are re-titled as The Sequel to the Tryal of the Witnesses and are revised by Sherlock
